newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Feed industry alters market plans over hog crisis.
newsitem.headline: Feed industry alters market plans over hog crisis.

text.p: Feed firms scrambled on Tuesday to cope with Taiwan's hog foot-and-mouth epidemic, refocussing on chicken feed and other other businesses to make up for their pig feed losses, executives said on Tuesday.

As soldiers carried out the slaughter of some 400,000 hogs, feed companies were suspending their pig feed operations and boosting chicken feed production in anticipation a public shift away from pork.
"We plan to close down our hog business in June, after calculating our losses," Lin Wen-chung, spokesman of leading feed firm Sino-Japan Feed Industry, told Reuters.
"We will concentrate on breeding chickens and producing chicken feed," Lin said.
Lin said the company expected to lose T$40 million (US$1.45 million) because of the outbreak of the deadly contagion.
Sino-Japan would reinvest in other industries and expected to earn a net profit of T$50 million (US$1.81 million) in the third quarter despite the epidemic.

Sino-Japan's shares on Tuesday rose T$0.8 to T$23.20, defying a panicky selloff that has sent many farm-sector firms to successive limit-down losses since officials reported the outbreak and banned all pork exports.
Great Wall Enterprise said its hog feed business, worth about T$900 million (US$32.72 million) a year, would decline sharply in 1997.
It too would shift to produce more chicken feed and increase chicken farming to try to tide over the hog business crisis, said Great Wall president Han Chia-huan.

The epidemic was expected to cost Taiwan in US$1.55 billion in lost exports and reduce the island's gross domestic product by up to one percentage point -- a staggering T$65.2 billion (US$2.37 billion) in 1996 terms.
The government order to slaughter all diseased pigs -- nearly 400,000 out of 14 million hog population -- has seriously battered the hog and its related industries, officials said.
Health and farm officials said the hog industry would need at least three years to recover, and pork exports to Taiwan's main market, Japan, might not resume for five years.
